001package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost;
002
003import static java.lang.Math.exp;
004import static java.lang.Math.log;
005import static java.lang.Math.sqrt;
006
007import java.io.Serializable;
008import java.util.List;
009import java.util.stream.Collectors;
010
011import org.immutables.value.Value;
012
013import io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.PhenomenologicalModel;
014import io.github.ai4ci.util.Conversions;
015import io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler;
016
017/**
018 * A phenomenological in-host model that tracks viral load and immune activity
019 * over time, supporting multiple exposures (e.g., reinfection or vaccination).
020 *
021 * <p>
022 * The model uses a <i>biphasic logistic function</i> to describe the rise and
023 * fall of viral load and immune response following each exposure. It supports
024 * superposition of multiple exposure events, where each contributes
025 * independently to the overall viral load and immunity.
026 *
027 * <p>
028 * The total viral load is computed as the <i>complementary probability</i> of
029 * no viral presence from any exposure: \[ V(t) = 1 - \prod_{e \in
030 * \text{exposures}} \left(1 - v_e(t)\right) \] where \( v_e(t) \) is the viral
031 * load contribution from exposure \( e \), modeled using a shifted biphasic
032 * logistic curve. This formulation assumes independent contributions and
033 * corresponds to the probability that at least one exposure is active at time
034 * \( t \).
035 *
036 * <p>
037 * Similarly, immune activity is aggregated as: \[ I(t) = 1 - \prod_{e \in
038 * \text{exposures}} \left(1 - i_e(t)\right) \] where \( i_e(t) \) is the immune
039 * response triggered by exposure \( e \).
040 *
041 * <p>
042 * This approach naturally captures:
043 * <ul>
044 * <li>Boosting of immunity from repeated exposures,</li>
045 * <li>Sub-threshold infections that contribute to immunity without causing
046 * disease,</li>
047 * <li>Waning immunity over time.</li>
048 * </ul>
049 *
050 * <p>
051 * The model is parameterized using observable clinical features (onset time,
052 * peak delay, etc.) and calibrated via logistic regression on key points of the
053 * curve.
054 *
055 * @see ExposureModel
056 * @see BiPhasicLogistic
057 */
058@Value.Immutable
059public interface InHostPhenomenologicalState
060                extends InHostModelState<PhenomenologicalModel> {
061
062        // static Logger log =
063        // LoggerFactory.getLogger(InHostPhenomenologicalState.class);
064
065        /**
066         * A biphasic logistic model for viral load or immune response dynamics.
067         *
068         * <p>
069         * The response is modeled as the product of a logistic growth phase and a
070         * logistic decay phase: \[ y(t) = f(t; r_g, s_g) \cdot \left(1 - f(t; r_d,
071         * s_d)\right) \] where:
072         * <ul>
073         * <li>\( f(t; r, s) = \frac{1}{1 + \exp(-r(t - s))} \) is the logistic
074         * function,</li>
075         * <li>\( r_g, s_g \): growth rate and midpoint,</li>
076         * <li>\( r_d, s_d \): decay rate and midpoint.</li>
077         * </ul>
078         *
079         * <p>
080         * This produces a unimodal curve with controllable rise, peak, and fall
081         * times. The model supports calibration from clinical data (onset, peak,
082         * duration).
083         */
084        @Value.Immutable
085        public static interface BiPhasicLogistic extends Serializable {
086
087                /**
088                 * Calibrates a biphasic logistic model for immune activity:
089                 *
090                 * <ul>
091                 * <li>\( t_{\text{peak}} \): time of peak immune response,</li>
092                 * <li>\( I_{\text{peak}} \): peak immune level,</li>
093                 * <li>\( t_{\text{half}} \): half-life of immune activity.</li>
094                 * </ul>
095                 *
096                 * The decay phase is calibrated from \( I_{\text{peak}} \) to \(
097                 * I_{\text{peak}}/2 \) over \( t_{\text{half}} \) days.
098                 *
099                 * @param peakTime  time of peak immune response
100                 * @param peakLevel peak immune activity level (0 \lt peak level \lt 1)
101                 * @param halfLife  half-life of immune activity (time to decay from peak
102                 *                  to half peak level)
103                 * @return a calibrated {@link BiPhasicLogistic} model for immune dynamics
104                 */
105                public static BiPhasicLogistic calibrateImmuneActivity(
106                                double peakTime, double peakLevel, double halfLife
107                ) {
108                        double halfPeakLevel = peakLevel / 2;
109                        peakLevel = sqrt(peakLevel);
110                        return ImmutableBiPhasicLogistic.builder()
111                                        .setGrowthRate(
112                                                        BiPhasicLogistic.rate(0, 0.01, peakTime, peakLevel)
113                                        )
114                                        .setGrowthTime(
115                                                        BiPhasicLogistic.time(0, 0.01, peakTime, peakLevel)
116                                        )
117                                        .setDecayRate(
118                                                        BiPhasicLogistic.rate(
119                                                                        peakTime, 1 - peakLevel, peakTime + halfLife,
120                                                                        1 - halfPeakLevel
121                                                        )
122                                        )
123                                        .setDecayTime(
124                                                        BiPhasicLogistic.time(
125                                                                        peakTime, 1 - peakLevel, peakTime + halfLife,
126                                                                        1 - halfPeakLevel
127                                                        )
128                                        ).build();
129                }
130
131                /**
132                 * Calibrates a biphasic logistic model for viral load using clinical
133                 * parameters:
134                 *
135                 * <ul>
136                 * <li>\( t_{\text{onset}} \): time of symptom onset,</li>
137                 * <li>\( \Delta t_{\text{peak}} \): delay to peak viral load,</li>
138                 * <li>\( \Delta t_{\text{post}} \): duration from peak to recovery
139                 * threshold,</li>
140                 * <li>\( y_{\text{threshold}} \): threshold for detectable virus,</li>
141                 * <li>\( y_{\text{peak}} \): peak viral load (square-root
142                 * transformed).</li>
143                 * </ul>
144                 *
145                 * The square root of \( y_{\text{peak}} \) is used to stabilize the
146                 * logistic fit.
147                 *
148                 * @param onsetTime        time of symptom onset
149                 * @param peakDelay        delay from onset to peak viral load
150                 * @param postPeakDuration duration from peak viral load to recovery
151                 *                         threshold
152                 * @param thresholdLevel   viral load level corresponding to the detection
153                 *                         threshold (0 \lt threshold level \lt 1)
154                 * @param peakLevel        viral load level corresponding to the peak (0
155                 *                         \lt peak level \lt 1)
156                 *
157                 * @return a calibrated {@link BiPhasicLogistic} model
158                 */
159                public static BiPhasicLogistic calibrateViralLoad(
160                                double onsetTime, double peakDelay, double postPeakDuration,
161                                double thresholdLevel, double peakLevel
162                ) {
163                        peakLevel = sqrt(peakLevel);
164                        return ImmutableBiPhasicLogistic.builder().setGrowthRate(
165                                        BiPhasicLogistic.rate(
166                                                        onsetTime, thresholdLevel, onsetTime + peakDelay, peakLevel
167                                        )
168                        ).setGrowthTime(
169                                        BiPhasicLogistic.time(
170                                                        onsetTime, thresholdLevel, onsetTime + peakDelay, peakLevel
171                                        )
172                        ).setDecayRate(
173                                        BiPhasicLogistic.rate(
174                                                        onsetTime + peakDelay, 1 - peakLevel,
175                                                        onsetTime + peakDelay + postPeakDuration,
176                                                        1 - thresholdLevel
177                                        )
178                        ).setDecayTime(
179                                        BiPhasicLogistic.time(
180                                                        onsetTime + peakDelay, 1 - peakLevel,
181                                                        onsetTime + peakDelay + postPeakDuration,
182                                                        1 - thresholdLevel
183                                        )
184                        ).build();
185                }
186
187                /**
188                 * Logistic function: \( f(x; r, s) = \frac{1}{1 + \exp(-r(x - s))} \)
189                 *
190                 * @param x input value
191                 * @param r growth/decay rate
192                 * @param s midpoint (inflection point)
193                 * @return logistic output in (0,1)
194                 */
195                private static double f(double x, double r, double s) {
196                        return 1 / (1 + exp(-r * (x - s)));
197                }
198
199                /**
200                 * Inverse logistic function: solves \( f(x; r, s) = y \) for \( x \): \[
201                 * x = s - \frac{1}{r} \log\left(\frac{1 - y}{y}\right) \]
202                 *
203                 * @param y target output (0 \lt y \lt 1)
204                 * @param r rate parameter
205                 * @param s midpoint
206                 * @return the input \( x \) that yields output \( y \)
207                 */
208                public static double invF(double y, double r, double s) {
209                        return s - log((1 - y) / y) / r;
210                }
211
212                /**
213                 * Computes the logistic rate \( r \) given two points \( (x_1, y_1) \),
214                 * \( (x_2, y_2) \): \[ r = \frac{\log\left(\frac{1 - y_2}{y_2}\right) -
215                 * \log\left(\frac{1 - y_1}{y_1}\right)}{x_1 - x_2} \] This is derived
216                 * from the inverse logistic formula.
217                 *
218                 * @param x1 first time point
219                 * @param y1 first value (0 \lt y1 \lt 1)
220                 * @param x2 second time point
221                 * @param y2 second value (0 \lt y2 \lt 1)
222                 * @return the rate parameter \( r \gt 0 \)
223                 * @throws RuntimeException if the computed rate is non-positive
224                 */
225                public static double rate(double x1, double y1, double x2, double y2) {
226                        double tmp = (log((1 - y2) / y2) - log((1 - y1) / y1)) / (x1 - x2);
227                        if (tmp < 0) throw new RuntimeException();
228                        return tmp;
229                }
230
231                /**
232                 * The characteristic time \( s \) (midpoint) of the logistic function two
233                 * points \( (x_1, y_1) \), \( (x_2, y_2) \).
234                 *
235                 * @param x1 time point
236                 * @param y1 value at time point \(0 \lt y1 \lt 1\)
237                 * @param x2 second time point
238                 * @param y2 second value \(0 \lt y2 \lt 1\)
239                 * @return the midpoint \( s \) corresponding to the given point and rate
240                 * @throws RuntimeException if the computed midpoint is negative
241                 */
242                public static double time(double x1, double y1, double x2, double y2) {
243                        double r = rate(x1, y1, x2, y2);
244                        return 1 / r * log((1 - y1) / y1) + x1;
245                }
246
247                /**
248                 * Computes the biphasic logistic response with shifted growth and decay
249                 * phases: \[ y(x) = f(x; r_g, s_g - g) \cdot \left(1 - f(x; r_d, s_d -
250                 * d)\right) \] where \( g \) and \( d \) are offsets that shift the curve
251                 * in time.
252                 *
253                 * @param x            time since exposure
254                 * @param growthOffset shift in growth phase
255                 * @param decayOffset  shift in decay phase
256                 * @return the adjusted response value
257                 */
258                default double adjusted(
259                                double x, double growthOffset, double decayOffset
260                ) {
261                        return f(
262                                        x, this.getGrowthRate(), this.getGrowthTime() - growthOffset
263                        ) * (1 - f(x, this.getDecayRate(), this.getDecayTime() - decayOffset));
264                }
265
266                /**
267                 * Returns the decay rate parameter \( r_d \) of the logistic function.
268                 *
269                 * @return the decay rate
270                 */
271                double getDecayRate();
272
273                /**
274                 * Returns the decay midpoint \( s_d \) of the logistic function.
275                 *
276                 * @return the decay time (midpoint)
277                 */
278                double getDecayTime();
279
280                /**
281                 * Returns the growth rate parameter \( r_g \) of the logistic function.
282                 *
283                 * @return the growth rate
284                 */
285                double getGrowthRate();
286
287                /**
288                 * Returns the growth midpoint \( s_g \) of the logistic function.
289                 *
290                 * @return the growth time (midpoint)
291                 */
292                double getGrowthTime();
293
294                /**
295                 * Computes the unit scaling factor for the logistic function, defined as
296                 * the value of the growth phase at time zero: \[ \text{unit} = f(0; r_g,
297                 * s_g) = \frac{1}{1 + \exp(-r_g(-s_g))} \] This represents the baseline
298                 * viral load corresponding to a normalized exposure dose of 1.
299                 *
300                 * @return the unit scaling factor for the logistic function
301                 */
302                @Value.Derived
303                default double getUnit() {
304                        return f(0, this.getGrowthRate(), this.getGrowthTime());
305                }
306
307                /**
308                 * Computes the unadjusted biphasic logistic response at time \( x \): \[
309                 * y(x) = f(x; r_g, s_g) \cdot \left(1 - f(x; r_d, s_d)\right) \]
310                 *
311                 * @param x time since exposure
312                 * @return the unshifted response value
313                 */
314                default double unadjusted(int x) {
315                        return f(x, this.getGrowthRate(), this.getGrowthTime())
316                                        * (1 - f(x, this.getDecayRate(), this.getDecayTime()));
317                }
318
319        }
320
321        /**
322         * Represents a single exposure event (infection or vaccination) that
323         * contributes to viral load and immune response.
324         *
325         * <p>
326         * Each exposure is characterized by:
327         * <ul>
328         * <li>Timing: when it occurred,</li>
329         * <li>Dose: normalized exposure level,</li>
330         * <li>Immune context: immune activity at time of exposure,</li>
331         * <li>Temporal offsets: shifts in the growth and decay phases of the
332         * response.</li>
333         * </ul>
334         *
335         * <p>
336         * The viral load from an exposure at time \( t \) is: \[ v_e(t) = f(t - t_e
337         * + g_e; r_g, s_g) \cdot \left(1 - f(t - t_e + d_e; r_d, s_d)\right) \]
338         * where:
339         * <ul>
340         * <li>\( t_e \): exposure time,</li>
341         * <li>\( g_e \): growth phase offset,</li>
342         * <li>\( d_e \): decay phase offset,</li>
343         * <li>\( f(x; r, s) = \frac{1}{1 + \exp(-r(x - s))} \): logistic
344         * function,</li>
345         * <li>\( r_g, s_g \): growth rate and midpoint,</li>
346         * <li>\( r_d, s_d \): decay rate and midpoint.</li>
347         * </ul>
348         *
349         * <p>
350         * The immune response is modeled similarly but without the decay modulation.
351         */
352        @Value.Immutable
353        public static interface ExposureModel extends Serializable {
354
355                /**
356                 * Minimum immune activity threshold below which an exposure is considered
357                 * irrelevant for future immune boosting.
358                 */
359                double MIN_IMMUNE_ACTIVITY = 0.001D;
360
361                /**
362                 * Factory method to create a new exposure with calibrated temporal
363                 * offsets.
364                 *
365                 * <p>
366                 * The growth offset \( g_e \) is computed so that the viral load at time
367                 * 0 of the exposure matches the scaled dose: \[ g_e = t_g - \frac{1}{r_g}
368                 * \log\left(\frac{1 - v_0}{v_0}\right) \] where \( v_0 = \text{dose}
369                 * \cdot \text{unit} \), and \( \text{unit} = f(0; r_g, s_g) \).
370                 *
371                 * <p>
372                 * The decay offset \( d_e \) is set to ensure the immune activity at
373                 * exposure matches the current level (but never shifted backward): \[ d_e
374                 * = \max\left(0, t_d - \frac{1}{r_d} \log\left(\frac{1 -
375                 * I(t)}{I(t)}\right)\right) \]
376                 *
377                 * @param exposure       normalized exposure dose (relative to infectious
378                 *                       dose)
379                 * @param immuneActivity current immune activity at time of exposure
380                 * @param viralLoad      model defining the shape of the response
381                 * @param time           time of exposure
382                 * @return a new exposure model with calibrated offsets
383                 */
384                public static ExposureModel createExposure(
385                                double exposure, double immuneActivity, BiPhasicLogistic viralLoad,
386                                int time
387                ) {
388
389                        double dose = exposure * viralLoad.getUnit();
390
391                        // Shift the growth curve backwards such that the growth curve starts
392                        // at the dose
393                        // at time zero. For exposures <1 this will be a shift forward and a
394                        // negative number
395                        double growthOffset = BiPhasicLogistic.invF(
396                                        dose, viralLoad.getGrowthRate(), viralLoad.getGrowthTime()
397                        );
398
399                        // Shift the decay curve such that the decay component is the same as
400                        // the current immune activity. Never shift it forwards
401                        double decayOffset = Math.max(
402                                        0,
403                                        BiPhasicLogistic.invF(
404                                                        immuneActivity, viralLoad.getDecayRate(),
405                                                        viralLoad.getDecayTime()
406                                        )
407                        );
408
409                        return ImmutableExposureModel.builder().setDecayOffset(decayOffset)
410                                        .setExposureTime(time).setGrowthOffset(growthOffset)
411                                        .setImmuneActivityAtExposure(immuneActivity)
412                                        .setNormalisedExposure(exposure).build();
413                }
414
415                /**
416                 * Returns the temporal offset applied to the decay phase of the response
417                 * curve. This offset shifts the decay curve to align with the immune
418                 * activity at exposure.
419                 *
420                 * @return the decay phase offset
421                 */
422                double getDecayOffset();
423
424                /**
425                 * Computes the immune activity contribution of this exposure at a given
426                 * time.
427                 *
428                 * <p>
429                 * If \( t \leq t_e \), returns 0. Otherwise: \[ i_e(t) = f(t - t_e; r_g,
430                 * s_g) \cdot \left(1 - f(t - t_e; r_d, s_d)\right) \] This represents the
431                 * unadjusted immune trajectory initiated by the exposure.
432                 *
433                 * @param time  the current time step
434                 * @param model the biphasic logistic model for immune dynamics
435                 * @return the immune activity from this exposure at the given time
436                 */
437                default double getExposureImmuneActivity(
438                                int time, BiPhasicLogistic model
439                ) {
440                        if (time <= this.getExposureTime()) return 0;
441                        return model.unadjusted(time - this.getExposureTime());
442                }
443
444                /**
445                 * Returns the time step at which this exposure occurred.
446                 *
447                 * @return the time of exposure
448                 */
449                public int getExposureTime();
450
451                /**
452                 * Computes the viral load contribution of this exposure at a given time.
453                 *
454                 * <p>
455                 * If \( t \leq t_e \), returns 0. Otherwise: \[ v_e(t) = f(t - t_e + g_e;
456                 * r_g, s_g) \cdot \left(1 - f(t - t_e + d_e; r_d, s_d)\right) \] This
457                 * biphasic form models rapid viral growth followed by immune-mediated
458                 * clearance.
459                 *
460                 * @param time  the current time step
461                 * @param model the biphasic logistic model defining growth and decay
462                 *              dynamics
463                 * @return the viral load from this exposure at the given time
464                 */
465                default double getExposureViralLoad(int time, BiPhasicLogistic model) {
466                        if (time <= this.getExposureTime()) return 0;
467                        return model.adjusted(
468                                        time - this.getExposureTime(), this.getGrowthOffset(),
469                                        this.getDecayOffset()
470                        );
471                }
472
473                /**
474                 * Returns the temporal offset applied to the growth phase of the response
475                 * curve. This offset shifts the growth curve in time to match the initial
476                 * viral load at exposure.
477                 *
478                 * @return the growth phase offset
479                 */
480                double getGrowthOffset();
481
482                /**
483                 * Returns the immune activity at the time of exposure. This value is used
484                 * to calibrate the decay offset of the response curve.
485                 *
486                 * @return the immune activity at the time of exposure
487                 */
488                public double getImmuneActivityAtExposure();
489
490                /**
491                 * Returns the normalized exposure dose for this event.
492                 *
493                 * @return the normalized exposure level (relative to infectious dose)
494                 */
495                public double getNormalisedExposure();
496
497                /**
498                 * Determines whether this exposure is no longer relevant for immune
499                 * boosting.
500                 *
501                 * <p>
502                 * An exposure is considered irrelevant if the time since exposure exceeds
503                 * the point at which the immune response has waned below 1% of its peak.
504                 * This is computed using the inverse logistic function to find the time
505                 * at which the decay phase falls below the threshold, and comparing it to
506                 * the current time.
507                 *
508                 * @param time  the current time step
509                 * @param model the biphasic logistic model for immune dynamics
510                 * @return true if this exposure is irrelevant for future immune boosting,
511                 *         false otherwise
512                 */
513                default boolean isIrrelevant(int time, BiPhasicLogistic model) {
514                        return this.getExposureTime() + BiPhasicLogistic
515                                        .invF(0.99, model.getDecayRate(), model.getDecayTime()) < time;
516                }
517
518        }
519
520        /**
521         * Returns the list of exposures that have occurred up to the current time.
522         * Each exposure is represented by an {@link ExposureModel} that captures its
523         * timing, dose and immune context. The list is used to compute the overall
524         * viral load and immune activity by aggregating contributions from all
525         * exposures.
526         *
527         * @return a list of exposure models representing past infection or
528         *         vaccination events
529         */
530        @Value.Redacted
531        List<ExposureModel> getExposures();
532
533        /**
534         * Computes the total immune activity at the current time by aggregating
535         * responses from all prior exposures.
536         *
537         * <p>
538         * Similar to viral load, immune activity is modeled as: \[ I(t) = 1 -
539         * \prod_{e} \left(1 - i_e(t)\right) \] where \( i_e(t) \) is the immune
540         * response from exposure \( e \), modeled using a logistic growth and decay
541         * process. This captures immune boosting and partial protection from
542         * sub-infectious doses.
543         *
544         * <p>
545         * The immune response is not reset by new infections; instead, it
546         * accumulates, reflecting immunological memory.
547         *
548         * @return the combined immune activity at the current time, in normalized
549         *         units
550         */
551        @Override @Value.Derived
552        default double getImmuneActivity() {
553                return 1 - this.getExposures().stream()
554                                .mapToDouble(
555                                                e -> e.getExposureImmuneActivity(
556                                                                this.getTime(), this.getImmunityModel()
557                                                )
558                                ).map(vl -> 1 - vl).reduce((d1, d2) -> d1 * d2).orElse(1);
559        }
560
561        /**
562         * Returns the biphasic logistic model used to compute immune response
563         * dynamics. This model is similarly calibrated and defines the shape of the
564         * immune response curve following each exposure. It is used by the
565         * {@link ExposureModel} to compute the immune activity contribution of each
566         * exposure at any given time.
567         *
568         * @return the biphasic logistic model for immune response dynamics
569         */
570        BiPhasicLogistic getImmunityModel();
571
572        /**
573         * Returns the viral load threshold above which the person is considered
574         * infectious. This cutoff is used to normalize the viral load and to
575         * determine infectiousness in transmission models.
576         *
577         * @return the viral load cutoff for infectiousness
578         */
579        double getInfectiousnessCutoff();
580
581        /**
582         * Computes a proxy for disease severity as the maximum viral load across all
583         * active exposures.
584         *
585         * <p>
586         * In this phenomenological model, severity is assumed to be driven by the
587         * peak viral load from any single exposure event: \[ S(t) = \max_{e} v_e(t)
588         * \] This reflects the idea that clinical outcomes are dominated by the most
589         * severe infection event, even in the presence of multiple exposures.
590         *
591         * @return the highest viral load contribution from any single exposure at
592         *         current time
593         */
594        @Override
595        default double getNormalisedSeverity() {
596                // In this model the viral load is the same as severity, but there is a
597                // question as to how to combine multiple exposures.
598
599                return this.getExposures().stream()
600                                .mapToDouble(
601                                                e -> e.getExposureViralLoad(
602                                                                this.getTime(), this.getViralLoadModel()
603                                                )
604                                ).max().orElse(0);
605        }
606
607        /**
608         * Returns the viral load normalized relative to the infectiousness cutoff.
609         *
610         * <p>
611         * The normalization is defined as: \[ V_{\text{norm}}(t) =
612         * \frac{V(t)}{V_{\text{cutoff}}} \] where \( V_{\text{cutoff}} \) is the
613         * minimum viral load required for infectiousness. This ratio is used in
614         * transmission models to compute transmissibility.
615         *
616         * @return normalized viral load relative to the infectiousness threshold
617         */
618        @Override
619        default double getNormalisedViralLoad() {
620                double tmp = Conversions
621                                .rateRatio(this.getViralLoad(), this.getInfectiousnessCutoff());
622                return tmp;
623        }
624
625        /**
626         * Returns the current time step in the in-host model. Time is measured in
627         * discrete units (e.g., days) since the start of the infection or
628         * simulation.
629         *
630         * @return the current time step
631         */
632        @Override
633        int getTime();
634
635        /**
636         * Computes the total viral load at the current time step by combining
637         * contributions from all prior exposures using probabilistic superposition.
638         *
639         * <p>
640         * Each exposure \( e \) contributes a viral load curve \( v_e(t) \), which
641         * is zero before the exposure time and follows a biphasic logistic function
642         * afterward. The overall viral load is computed as the complement of the
643         * probability that <i>none</i> of the exposures are active: \[ V(t) = 1 -
644         * \prod_{e} \left(1 - v_e(t)\right) \] This formulation assumes independence
645         * between exposure events and corresponds to the union of their individual
646         * effects.
647         *
648         * @return the combined viral load at the current time, in normalized units
649         */
650        @Value.Derived
651        default double getViralLoad() {
652                return 1 - this.getExposures().stream()
653                                .mapToDouble(
654                                                e -> e.getExposureViralLoad(
655                                                                this.getTime(), this.getViralLoadModel()
656                                                )
657                                ).map(vl -> 1 - vl).reduce((d1, d2) -> d1 * d2).orElse(1);
658        }
659
660        /**
661         * Returns the biphasic logistic model used to compute viral load dynamics.
662         * This model is calibrated from clinical parameters and defines the shape of
663         * the viral load curve following each exposure. It is used by the
664         * {@link ExposureModel} to compute the viral load contribution of each
665         * exposure at any given time.
666         *
667         * @return the biphasic logistic model for viral load dynamics
668         */
669        BiPhasicLogistic getViralLoadModel();
670
671        /**
672         * Advances the in-host state by one time step, updating exposures and
673         * immune/viral dynamics.
674         *
675         * <p>
676         * The update process:
677         * <ol>
678         * <li>Removes exposures that are no longer relevant (immune response has
679         * waned below 1%),</li>
680         * <li>Processes a new exposure (if any), scaling the initial viral dose by
681         * host susceptibility,</li>
682         * <li>Creates a new {@link ExposureModel} with appropriate growth and decay
683         * offsets,</li>
684         * <li>Increments the time counter.</li>
685         * </ol>
686         *
687         * <p>
688         * The new exposure's initial viral load is: \[ v_0 =
689         * \text{Conversions.scaleProbabilityByRR}(V_{\text{cutoff}},
690         * \text{virionDose}) \] which adjusts the baseline infectious dose by the
691         * exposure intensity.
692         *
693         * @param sampler          unused in this deterministic model (reserved for
694         *                         stochastic extensions)
695         * @param virionDose       the magnitude of new viral exposure (relative to
696         *                         infectious dose)
697         * @param immunisationDose currently unused; reserved for explicit vaccine
698         *                         modeling
699         * @return a new state advanced by one time unit with updated exposures
700         */
701        @Override
702        default InHostPhenomenologicalState update(
703                        Sampler sampler, double virionDose, double immunisationDose
704        ) { // , double immuneModifier) {
705                        // Overall modifiers are a number around 1:
706                        // Double hostImmunity = immuneModifier;
707
708                double virionsDx = this.getInfectiousnessCutoff();
709                int time = this.getTime();
710                double virionExposure = Conversions
711                                .scaleProbabilityByRR(virionsDx, virionDose);
712
713                // Check for exposures that are no longer relevant from the purposes
714                // of contributing to overall immunity... I should probably refactor
715                // this.
716                List<ExposureModel> tmp = this.getExposures().stream()
717                                .filter(em -> !em.isIrrelevant(time + 1, this.getImmunityModel()))
718                                .collect(Collectors.toList());
719
720                ImmutableInHostPhenomenologicalState.Builder out = ImmutableInHostPhenomenologicalState
721                                .builder().from(this).setExposures(tmp);
722
723                // add new exposure from today
724                if (virionExposure > 0) {
725                        ExposureModel tmp2 = ExposureModel.createExposure(
726                                        virionExposure, this.getImmuneActivity(),
727                                        // Conversions.scaleProbability(this.getImmuneActivity(),
728                                        // hostImmunity),
729                                        this.getViralLoadModel(), time
730                        );
731                        out.addExposure(tmp2);
732                }
733
734                return out.setTime(time + 1).build();
735        }
736
737}
